body: @dguy Could we update the public API java doc string of the possible thrown exception as well? Also with all the transient errors we are now exposing to users during rebalances, could we consider auto handling them inside the libraries?
Is the `org.apache.kafka.streams.integration.QueryableStateIntegrationTest.queryOnRebalance[1]` related to an existing PR?

@guozhangwang i can add the java-doc string, no problem. If we want to auto-handle in the library then i'll raise a JIRA. However, if we auto-handle then we are going to need to add some extra config, i.e, StreamsConfig.SOME_NAME_RETRY_TIMEOUT (i can't think of what i'd call it!). The idea being that you only retry until the timeout has passed.
If you think this is good, let me know and i'll raise a JIRA and put it all into this patch.
@guozhangwang it is this one: https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1845
@guozhangwang @dguy @enothereska Just saw the comments! Seems that github notifications were not sent to my email. Will look into the comments and address them soon!

@dguy I'm just a bit concerned about the fact that exposing all these transient errors directly to users from various places (in `KafkaStreams` in discover step, `ReadableXXX` classes etc in the query step) may increase the burden on user's end, and I'm wondering if we can provide similar functionalities like a normal consumer client whereas rebalances are abstracted from the user.

More concretely, right now we are using the exception to differentiate from case 1) information not available (either for `StreamsMetadata`, for getting `V value` from `K key` on `readable...`) yet, which is transient, to case 2) where the information does exist but indicates `null`, (e.g. either `there is not store with this name`, or `no store with this name and contain this key`, or `no key exist in this readable store`). Then users can interpret these differentiated cases themselves, for example:
1. return with the previously read value: for example, for a monitoring UI, you'd prefer `stale` values than a red-flagged `N/A`.
2. block-and-retry: this is when `stale` value is not acceptable, and users would rather wait than reporting an old value.
3. etc.

In Kafka Consumer, we are actually NOT differentiating these two cases but introduce a wait timeout on `poll` / etc functions. However, for Kafka Streams, since rebalance can take long time and since the library is, in fact, exposing the rebalances throw hosted tasks anyways I feel it is actually not the right path to follow. Instead, could we still differentiate these two cases but in a slightly different manner:
1. Introduce a sentinel `StreamsMetadata` indicating "information not available" instead of throwing `StreamsException` and `InvalidStateStoreException`; and users getting this value should handle themselves following the above possible options.
2. Still throw `InvalidStateStoreException` in `getXXX` calls in `readableStoreYYY`, but with a different exception message indicating that "the state store may have migrated to another instance", instead of "it is not (re)-initialized yet"; and users should handle this by going back to step 1) in order to re-discover the instance hosting the store.

Note that this is small change compared with using exceptions in step 1) to differentiate "information not available" from "it is null", but I feel it is easier for users to interpret. If you agree, we can proceed and make the changes in this PR.
Also ping @hjafarpour @mjsax to review.
Also ping @mjsax to review.
Ping @dguy @enothereska @mjsax @hjafarpour for reviews.

@dguy The only exception I was thinking about for post-KIP4 is `consumer.commitSync`, when it throws `CommitFailedException` which usually indicate a rebalance happens behind the scene and this task is no longer owned by the consumer. Today we throw this exception all the way to the users as well but we can actually auto-handle it by just closing the task since we know it has migrated to another instance already.

We can probably do this in a different JIRA, so I will just move ahead to review the current PR as you are working to complete this WIP.
Looks like the Jenkins run aborted because of a timeout, not a failure.
LGTM
@guozhangwang sounds good - i'll raise a JIRA for it too. Thanks

@vahidhashemian Yeah, I'm leaning toward considering this an error. It's certainly possible (from the protocol level) to join the group with an empty subscription, but it's difficult to see the value of it since it ensures that no partitions will be assigned and we'll block in poll() until the timeout elapses. It seems more likely that an empty subscription/assignment indicates an error, so raising is probably the appropriate action. Use cases where a subscription can become empty are probably rare and it would be easy to restructure the code to avoid the poll() in that case.

This reuslt has 2 problems:
1. It still blocks `producer.send()`
2. NetworkClient initiates connection to all brokers before sending the first metadata request.

I digged into DefaultMetadataUpdater and found that [timeToNextReconnectAttempt](https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/NetworkClient.java#L542) is causing this.

The cause of problem 1 is that DefaultMetadataUpdater updates `lastNoNodeAvailableMs` even when a connection is being established to a broker, which leads `retry.backoff.ms` interval among each `maybeUpdate()`.
The cause of problem 2 is that DefaultMetadataUpdater is not waiting a connection being established to a broker in the previous loop. By changing `maybeUpdate()` to wait a connection being established properly, maybeUpdate() is no longar riskly to call in tight loop so we can let each loop of maybeUpdate() to try checking connection availability for sending metadata request.

After appling 64ec2ec, the experiment result look like this:

```
./bin/kafka-run-class.sh -Dlog4j.configuration=file:./log4j.properties -Dretry.backoff.ms=5000 KafkaProducerMetadataUpdateDurationTest
```

ping @junrao . Will you able to take a look?

Some context on the patch. The current expiration mechanism is based on the muted partitions in the `RecordAccumulator`, if a batch has sit in the accumulator for some time and there is no in flight batch for that partition, we will expire the batch. This behavior is introduced in KAFKA-3388( #1056 ). The issue is that when metadata update happens, we will not send any other request in that send loop, so no partition will be muted and thus are exposed to expiration in that send loop even though they can still make progress. This caused our mirror maker to shutdown from time to time. The fix is to let the expiration check base on the metadata freshness. If the metadata is fresh and the leader is known, we don't expire a batch.

@kawamuray Thanks for the reminder. I'll look at this in the morning.

One meta comments: we are adding more and more integration tests that our stream unit test has taken about 10X more time than 6 month ago. And in general for cases where we need to bring up more than one Kafka servers or KStream instances, we should really move them to the ducktape tests and keep unit tests, including integration tests, more modular. Perhaps we can do that later in a separate JIRA.

@guozhangwang - The `TaskAssignor` doesn't assign the standby tasks to the same process. So if `num.threads` = 0 and `num.standby` > 0 you only get the active task assigned. Which seems correct to me as there isn't anywhere for the standby to run.
The change of threads to 1 fixed the system test as all the threads in the same `KafkaStreams` instance were being assigned the same set of standby tasks, hence they were competing for the same locks.
LGTM
@junrao Thank you, I have rebased the PR.

@rnpridgeon, I don't know the original reason, but one reason to validate the regex is that we use the hostname in a number of places where there are character restrictions. One alternative would be to encode invalid characters in such cases.

We should definitely fix the error message. Feel free to include that in this PR since it should be a small change.
@junrao Let me know if this is what you had in mind.

@ijuma that makes sense, I'll look into that possibility real quick. Worst case scenario we should put the derived hostname in the message as opposed to the original. That way you can see in the error message that he url has been truncated

@hachikuji By doing the check on the client side, if one of the offsets to commit is invalid we'll have to throw an error and cancel the whole request. Is that acceptable ?

Should we do attempt to do a KIP to properly fix this on the server side ?
LGTM and merged to trunk. Great work @enothereska and @dguy !!
@enothereska @dguy Could we also create corresponding JIRAs for the open questions in this PR just in case we forgot? Thanks.

I raised: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4182
not sure if there was anything else?

@mimaison I'm not sure I see the complication. It seems preferable to catch the invalid offsets before the request is sent to the coordinator and raise an `IllegalArgumentException`, though it would be more ideal if the server also had a check. A KIP may be the way to go if we think the lack of a server-side check is a significant problem. What did you think about my previous suggestion to not allow commits on offsets which are greater than the current position?
